rea.data package

Submodules

rea.data.data module

class rea.data.data.Data(input_path: str, output_path: str, label_col: Union[int, str], dataset_name: str, original_shape: Optional[List[int]] = None, test_size: float = 0.3, cat_conv_method: str = 'woe', categorical_columns: Optional[Union[List[str], List[int]]] = None, seed: int = 42, scale_data: bool = False)[source]

Bases: object

Module to handle the data acquisition and preprocessing.

__init__(input_path: str, output_path: str, label_col: Union[int, str], dataset_name: str, original_shape: Optional[List[int]] = None, test_size: float = 0.3, cat_conv_method: str = 'woe', categorical_columns: Optional[Union[List[str], List[int]]] = None, seed: int = 42, scale_data: bool = False)[source]

Create a new instance of the data module.

Parameters

  • input_path – Filepath to the dataset in csv format

  • output_path – Path to the folder to fill with output

  • label_col – index or name of the column containing the labels

  • dataset_name – friendly name to give to the dataset

  • test_size – percentage of the data used for testing

  • categorical_columns – List of categorical columns to be converted in the dataset

  • cat_conv_method – Method for categorical conversion

  • seed – random seed for data splitting

  • scale_data – flag to MinMaxScale the input data

classmethod _conv_cat_scikit(x: numpy.ndarray, feature_names: List[str], categorical_columns: List[str], cat_conv_key: str, y: numpy.ndarray) → Tuple[numpy.ndarray, list[str]][source]

Convert the categorical columns in the given data points to numerical using a scikit learn method from Data.cat_encoder_methods.

Parameters

  • x – The input dataset to convert columns from

  • categorical_columns – The list of column names for x

  • categorical_columns – The list of categorical column names

  • cat_conv_key – Name encoding of scikit-learn method

Returns

The converted data of x and the new feature_names

static _convert_categorical_woe(x: numpy.ndarray, y: numpy.ndarray, categorical_columns: List[int], class_names: List[str], feature_names: List[str]) → Tuple[numpy.ndarray, Dict[str, Dict[str, numpy.ndarray]], List[str]][source]

Convert the categorical columns in the given data points to numerical using WoE Encoding.

Since WoE encoding is normally based on binary decisions, we split an n-dimensional decision into n binary decisions and calculate a vector based encoding on those. See here for more detail on WoE

Parameters

  • x – The input dataset to convert columns from

  • y – The decisions for each point in x

  • categorical_columns – The list of column indices of x that are to be converted

  • class_names – The list of class names

Returns

Tuple of converted points, leaving the original columns intact and a Dictionary containing a Dictionary for each converted column, where the latter includes the encodings for each column value

static _get_class_weights(y_train: numpy.ndarray) → Dict[int, float][source]

Calculate the weights for each class to determine the balancing of the dataset.

Parameters

y_train – The model labels

Returns

The weights for each class.

static _split_labels(dataset: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, label_col: Union[int, str]) → Tuple[numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray, List[str], List[str]][source]

Split the given dataset into attributes and labels and transform it to an array

Parameters

  • label_col – The index or name of the column containing the labels

Returns

static _split_test(x: numpy.ndarray, y: numpy.ndarray, seed: int, test_size: float) → Tuple[numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray, numpy.ndarray][source]

Split the dataset into model and testing datasets using scikit-learns train_test_split

Parameters

  • x – The attributes

  • y – The labels

  • seed – The seed to use for the rng

  • test_size – The proportion of entries used for testing

Returns

Tuple of model, testing data in the form (x_train, x_test, y_train, y_test)
